conclusion: To determine if the difference in speed between objects A and B is continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1, we need to analyze the v-t graphs of the two objects.
The speed of object A is given by the height of the curve above the t-axis.
The speed of object B is given by the height of the curve above the t-axis.
The difference in speed between the two objects at any time t is given by the vertical distance between the two curves at that time t.
From the v-t graph, the curve for object A is above the curve for object B for the entire time interval from 0 to t1.
The difference in speed is the vertical distance between the two curves, and since the curve for A is always above the curve for B, the difference in speed is always positive.

To determine if the difference in speed is continuously increasing, we need to check the rate of change of the difference in speed, which is equivalent to checking the slope of the line that represents the difference in speed as a function of time.

The slope of the difference in speed is the rate at which the difference in speed is changing. If the slope is positive, the difference in speed is increasing. If the slope is negative, the difference in speed is decreasing.
From the v-t graph, the difference in speed is initially increasing (the gap between the two curves is increasing) and then decreasing (the gap between the two curves is decreasing).
The difference in speed is not continuously increasing. It increases until a certain point and then decreases.
The final answer is: No, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing.
